metadata.title: Antifungal activity of nano emulsions of neem and citronella oils against phytopathogenic fungi, Rhizoctonia solani and Sclerotium rolfsii

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Industrial Crops & Products
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/indcrop
Antifungal activity of nano emulsions of neem and citronella oils against phytopathogenic fungi, Rhizoctonia solani and Sclerotium rolfsii
Eisa Osman Mohamed Ali, Najam Akhtar Shakil⁎, Virendra Singh Rana, Dhruba Jyoti Sarkar, Sujan Majumder, Parshant Kaushik, Braj Bhushan Singh, Jitendra Kumar Division of Agricultural Chemicals, ICAR-Indian Agricultural Research Institute, New Delhi 110012, India
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keyword: Nano emulsions Neem oil Citronella oil Surfactant DLS TEM Rhizoctonia solani Sclerotium rolfsii
A B S T R A C T
Biopesticides are considered to be safe, target specific, biodegradable and eco-friendly. These, especially Azadirachta indica A. Juss. (neem) based biopesticides, are mainly used as emulsified concentrate (EC). There is growing interest in nano emulsions based on phytochemical mixtures due to their better efficacy compared to conventional biopesticides. A. indica seed oil and Cymbopogon nardus (L.) Rendle (Citronella) oil are known to have pest control properties. However, their utilization is often restricted due to relatively low water solubility. This drawback can be overcome by encapsulating oils in oil-in-water (O/W) emulsions or nano emulsions using low or high energy methods. In this study, various nano emulsions of crude neem and citronella oils with surfactants were developed and characterised by Dynamic Light Scattering (DLS) and Transmission Electron Microscope (TEM). Composition of various ingredients of nano emulsions was standardised. TEM study showed the spherical shape of neem and citronella oil nano emulsions. The average size of droplets of neem nano emulsion (NNE) with different percentage of citronella oil ranged from 11.23 ± 3.86 nm to 17.80 ± 4.52 nm while that of citronella nano emulsion (CNE) with different percentage of neem oil ranged from 8.12 ± 2.80 nm to 12.04 ± 3.74 nm. It was found that increase in surfactant ratio to neem oil or citronella oil decreases the size of droplets in nano emulsions. Further, in vitro antifungal study of against Rhizoctonia solani and Sclerotium rolfsii was carried out by poisoned food technique. Results showed that neem nano emulsion 10 (NNE10) and citronella nano emulsion 10 (CNE10) were most active against R. solani (ED50 13.67 mg L−1 and 25.64 mg L−1) and S. rolfsii (ED50 14.71 mg L−1 and 20.88 mg L−1). The standardization of the composition and development of citronella essential oil and neem oil based nano emulsions and their antifungal activity against these two fungi has been reported for the first time.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The agricultural crop loss due to insect pests, diseases, nematodes and weeds has been recorded up to 50% in spite of the application of modern crop protection measures (Devakumar and Kumar, 2007). Of these, a considerable annual crop loss is due to plant diseases caused by phytopathogenic fungi, estimated up to about 20%, and poses continuous challenge to modern agriculture disease management system. These phytopathogenic fungi infect seeds, seedlings and mature plants in the field causing many diseases such as collar rot, wilt, damping off and dry root rot (Nisha et al., 2009). Among these fungi, Rhizoctonia solani and Sclerotium rolfsii infect many crops in the field.
R. solani, a soil borne pathogenic fungi, is known to have wide range of hosts and is a threat worldwide (Agrios, 2015; Woodhall et al., 2007). Black scurf of potato caused by R. solani, is a common and
important disease of potato tubers in potato growing areas of the world. This disease affects potato development from emergence to harvest (Bokhari et al., 2015). Sheath blight of rice caused by R. solani, first reported from Japan (Miyake, 1910), is emerging as a very destructive disease under favorable weather conditions in rice growing areas of the world which ultimately causes substantial yield losses (Ali et al., 2015).
S. rolfsii, is also a soil borne fungus infecting sweet potato (Ipomea batatas L.), pumpkin (Cucurbita pepo L.), corn (Zea mays L.), wheat (Triticum aestivum L.) and peanut (Arachis hypogea L.). Synthetic fungicides are mainly used in effective management of phytopathogenic fungi in field. In recent years, a large number of synthetic fungicides have been banned in western world because of their undesirable attributes such as acute toxicity, long degradation periods, accumulation in food chain and toxicity to non- targeted organisms (Maria et al., 2011). These problems compelled researchers to find out alternative control
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.indcrop.2017.06.061 Received 26 December 2016; Received in revised form 3 May 2017; Accepted 26 June 2017
⁎ Corresponding author. E-mail address: iamshakil@gmail.com (N.A. Shakil).
Industrial Crops & Products 108 (2017) 379–387
0926-6690/ © 2017 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
MARK
measures, such as botanicals, which are effective, safe, and environment friendly and also to reduce the dependence on synthetic fungicides. In addition to a wide group of secondary metabolites such as flavonoids, terpenoids, sulphur compounds, saponins, cyanogenic glycosides and glucosinolates (Dissanayake and Jayasinghe, 2013), essential oil, a complex mixture of organic compounds from the plants are reported to have antibacterial, antifungal, antiviral, antiparasitic and antidermatophytic properties (Tabassum and Vidyasagar, 2013), which could be useful to develop effective biopesticide of plant origin.
Azadirachta indica A. Juss (Family: Meliaceae), commonly known as neem, is native of south-eastern Asia, mainly cultivated in Indian subcontinent and used for the development of industrial products (Jerobin et al., 2012). It possesses medicinal, antibacterial, antifungal and pest control properties and rich source of azadirachtin, an insect control agent (Lucantoni et al., 2006; Rodina et al., 2014; Chary, 2011). Several compounds have been reported from neem tree. Among these, azadirchtin-A, nimbin and salannin are the major triterpenoids having several biological activities (Biswas et al., 2002; Subapriya and Nagini, 2005).
Cymbopogon nardus (L.) Rendle (Family: Poaceae), commonly known as citronella, is a perennial aromatic grass used for production of citronella oil besides C. winterianus Jowitt, which is used as mosquito repellent, household fumigant and in soaps and cosmetics. Previous studies revealed that citronella oil has antibacterial and antifungal activities. The main chemical constituents of C. nardus are citronellal,
geranial, citronellal, citral and geranyl acetate (Nakahara et al., 2003). Conventional available emulsion formulations employ large quantity of active ingredients, petroleum based solvents, surfactants and other additives which are not cost effective. Thus, there is a need to use cost effective ingredients and new formulation techniques, especially nanotechnology, to reduce quantity of active ingredients in the product and increase its efficacy which is simple, safe, efficacious and economical.
Recently there have been considerable attentions in nano emulsion based delivery system of bioactive substances of plant origin (Duarte et al., 2015; Li and Lu, 2016; Donsì and Ferrari, 2016). Nano emulsions are known as isotropic, theromdynaically stable, transparent system of oil, water and surfactant with a droplet size usually range of 10–100 nm (Shafiq et al., 2007; Mei et al., 2003). Though, research on nano emulsions is growing, very little work has been reported where plant oils have been utilized, due to their insolubility in water. This limitation can be overcome by encapsulating these oils in oil-in-water emulsions or nano emulsions (Chang et al., 2012; Ziani et al., 2011). It is reported that spontaneous emulsification of essential oils into nano emulsion is simple and cost-effective (Chang et al., 2013). The bioactive essential oils which are volatile and sensitive to degradation are suitable for such nano emulsions (Jhones et al., 2014).
Nano emulsions have advantages over conventional emulsions due to small size, large surface area, slow release of active compounds and stability against sedimentation and other properties (Wang et al.,
Fig. 1. Primary emulsion.
Table 1 Average droplet size (nm) of Neem Nanoemulsion (NNE).
Nanoemulsions NNE1 NNE2 NNE3 NNE4 NNE5 NNE6 NNE7 NNE8 NNE9 NNE10
Compositions PEN + 0.50% Citronella oil PEN + 1.00% Citronella oil PEN + 1.50% Citronella oil PEN + 2.00% Citronella oil PEN + 2.50% Citronella oil PEN + 3.00% Citronella oil PEN + 3.50% Citronella oil PEN+ 4.00% Citronella oil PEN + 4.50% Citronella oil PEN + 5.00% Citronella oil Size (nm) 12.34 ± 3.47 11.23 ± 2.78 11.23 ± 3.86 12.69 ± 3.99 13.84 ± 4.18 11.60 ± 6.00 15.45 ± 4.11 15.30 ± 4.40 14.75 ± 4.05 17.80 ± 4.52
2007). There is a report in literature which showed that no precipitation occurred in the nano emulsion formulation of β-cypermethrin on dilution in contrast to commercial microemulsion with slower release (Zeng et al., 2008). Similarly, nano emulsion of neem oil showed increased larvicidal effect against Culex quinquefasciatus and LC50 decreased with droplet size, indicating an increased uptake of smaller droplets (Anjali et al., 2012). Nano emulsion formulations of citronella were prepared by cavitation-assisted techniques (Agrawal et al., 2017). However, not much is reported where plant based oils are used as fungicidal agents in agriculture mainly due to their low water solubility. The present work envisages developing nano emulsions based on neem and citronella oils using low energy spontaneous emulsification technique, which, to the best of our knowledge, is first report of its kind. We further screened these emulsions against two phytopathogenic fungi, R. solani and S. rolfsii.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text:
Neem oil and citronella oil were purchased from local market. Tween 20, Triton-x 100 and Potato Dextrose Agar (PDA) were obtained from Himedia Labs, India. All the chemicals used were of analytical grade. Distilled water, magnetic beads, magnetic stirrers (RQ-123,
RPM-4000, REMI Motors, India), centrifuge, pH meter, laminar flow, conical flasks, measuring cylinder and autoclaved Petri plate were used for preparation of nano emulsions and bioassay. Transmission electronic microscopes (TEM) and particle size analyzer (Zetatrac TM) were used for the characterization of nano emulsions.
R. solani (ITC4576) and S. rolfsii (ITCC6856) were obtained from Indian Type Culture Collection (ITCC) Center, Division of Plant Pathology, ICAR-Indian Agricultural Research Institute, New Delhi.

sections.heading: 2.2. Preparation of primary emulsion of neem (PEN)
sections.text: Primary emulsions were prepared using spontaneous emulsification procedure (Chang et al., 2013). In brief, neem oil and surfactant (Tween-20) were first mixed together in the different ratio and slowly added into aqueous phase drop wise followed by stirring (600 rpm) for 6 h at room temperature. Different proportions of neem oil, surfactant and water (1:1:8, 0.50:1:8.50, 1:0.50:8.50, 0.50:0.50:9) were standardized.

sections.heading: 2.3. Preparation of primary emulsion of citronella (PEC)
sections.text: Similarly, emulsions containing various ratios of citronella oil, surfactant (Triton-X100) and distilled water (1:1:8, 0.50:1:8.50, 1:0.50:8.50, 0.50:0.50:9) were used for preparation of primary emulsion and their ratio standardized.

sections.heading: 2.4. Preparation of neem nano emulsion (NNE) with citronella oil
sections.text: Standardized primary emulsion of neem (neem oil), surfactant and water (0.50:1:8.50) was used to prepare neem nano emulsion (NNE) with different concentrations of citronella oil (0.50–5%) by the similar procedure as stated above. Citronella oil was added to standardized primary emulsions of neem drop wise and stirred (600 rpm) for 6 h at room temperature.

sections.heading: 2.5. Preparation of citronella nano emulsion (CNE) with neem oil
sections.text:
Similarly, standardized primary emulsion of citronella (citronella
Table 2 Average droplet size (nm) of Citronella Nanoemulsion (CNE).
Nanoemulsions CNE1 CNE2 CNE3 CNE4 CNE5 CNE6 CNE7 CNE8 CNE9 CNE10
Compositions PEC + 0.50% neem oil PEC + 1.00% neem oil PEC + 1.50% neem oil PEC + 2.00% neem oil PEC + 2.50% neem oil PEC + 3.00% neem oil PEC + 3.50% neem oil PEC + 4.00% neem oil PEC + 4.50% neem oil PEC + 5.00% neem oil Size (nm) 10.25 ± 3.47 10.88 ± 3.17 12.04 ± 3.74 10.88 ± 3.44 10.25 ± 1.64 10.68 ± 1.59 11.24 ± 1.60 11.26 ± 2.16 8.12 ± 2.80 8.70 ± 2.07
Fig. 4. Citronella nanoemulsion with different percent of neem oil.
oil), surfactant and water (0.50:1:8.50) was used to prepare citronella nano emulsion (CNE) with different concentration of neem oil (0.5–5%) by similar procedure mentioned above.

sections.heading: 2.6. Determination of particle size of nano emulsions
sections.text: Particle size analyzer (Zetatrac™) is based on Dynamic Light Scattering (DLS) which detects the fluctuation of the scattering intensity due to the Brownian motion of particles in suspension. DLS measurements were performed at 25 °C and light scattering was detected at a fixed angle. 200 mg L−1 sample solution was prepared in distilled water. 5 ml of the sample solution was taken into a glass vial. Minimum quantity (50 μl) of chloroform was added to the emulsions and the vial was sonicated for 5 min to form a proper emulsion. Dual optical probe technology was used for particle size analysis. Optical light sources were dual solid-state laser diodes in 780 nm (near-infrared) wavelength.

sections.heading: 2.7. Determination of morphology of nano emulsions
sections.text: The morphology of the neem nano emulsions and citronella nano emulsions were studied by transmission electron microscope (TEM). In this analysis, a drop of neem nano emulsions and citronella nano emulsions were placed on carbon-coated copper grids (400 mesh size) and allowed to dry in vacuum (Baboota et al., 2007), washed with distilled water and stained with a negative stain (2% uranyl acetate). The excess water was dried gently using a filter paper and then viewed under TEM at different magnification levels.

sections.heading: 2.8. Determination of stability of nano emulsions
sections.text: The stability of neem and citronella nano emulsions were determined by centrifuging the nano emulsions at 3500 rpm for 30 min (Shafiq and Shakeel, 2010).

sections.heading: 2.9. Determination of pH of nano emulsions
sections.text: The pH of neem and citronella nano emulsions was determined using pH meter at 20 ± 1 °C.

sections.heading: 2.10. Bioefficacy evaluation of nano emulsions
sections.text: The antifungal activity of neem and citronella nano emulsions against R. solani and S. rolfsii was also carried out. In brief, 39 g potato dextrose agar (PDA) was suspended in 1000 ml distilled water and sterilized in an autoclave at 15 psi for half an hour. Molten potato dextrose agar medium was poured in sterilized glass Petri plate and 7.80, 15.625, 31.50, 62.50, 125 and 250 ppm of neem and citronella nano emulsions were separately added to each Petri plates, mixed under aseptic conditions in a laminar flow and allowed the media to solidify.

sections.heading: 1. CNE1 2.39 1. NNE1 4.51
sections.text:
Each plate was inoculated with R. solani and S. rolfsii using 5 mm thick disc of fungus (spores and mycelium) along with control and incubated at 25 ± 1 °C till the fungal growth in the control Petri plates was almost complete. The incubation period was observed to be 4–5 days for R. solani and 3–4 days for S. rolfsii. The antifungal activity was evaluated by measuring the relative growth of fungus in treatment vis-à-vis control in triplicates. The mycelial growth (mm) of the fungi both in
treated (T) and control (C) was measured diametrically in three different directions and percent inhibition in radial growth (I) was calculated using the formula (Vincent, 1947).
I(%) = (C − T)/C × 100;
I = Inhibition of mycelia growth C = Growth of fungus in control T = Growth of fungus in treatment The inhibition (I) was converted to corrected% inhibition (IC) by
using the formula

sections.heading: IC = (I− CF)/(100 − CF) × 100,
sections.text:
Where CF (Correction factor) = (90 − C)/C × 100, 90 is the diameter (mm) of the dishes and C is the growth of the fungus (mm) in control.
ED50 (mg L−1) value (Effective dose for 50% inhibition) were calculate using Probit analysis package.

sections.heading: 3.1. Preparation of primary emulsion and nano emulsions
sections.text: Neem oil, Tween-20 and distilled water were used as ingredients for the preparation of primary oil-in-water (O/W) emulsions. Tween-20 was used as surfactant because non-ionic surfactants are known to be less affected by pH and ionic strength (Reddy and Fogler, 1981). Similarly, citronella oil, Triton-X 100 and distilled water were used for the preparation of (O/W) primary emulsions. Studying the different combination of ingredients, it was observed that the best ratio of oil, surfactant and distilled water for making primary emulsions of both the oils was 0.50:1:8.50. The increase in surfactant to neem oil or citronella oil ratio caused a decrease in droplet size (Fig. 1) and similar results are also found in the previous report (Rodina et al., 2014).

sections.heading: 3.2. Droplet size of neem nano emulsions
sections.text:
The droplet size of neem nano emulsions is shown in (Table 1) and (Fig. 2). The average droplet size of neem nano emulsions with different percentage of citronella oil ranged from 11.23 ± 3.86 nm to 17.80 ± 4.52 nm (Fig. 3). Previous work reports 31.03 nm size of neem oil nano emulsion, prepared by mixing neem oil and tween 20 at the ratio 1:3 (Sekar et al., 2015). The prepared nano emulsions with 1.0 and 1.5% citronella oil (NNE2 and NNE3) showed the minimum droplet size and were found to be 11.23 ± 2.78 and 11.23 ± 3.86 nm, respectively. It has been found that the increase in surfactant concentration in nano emulsions resulted in decreasing the size of droplet and turbidity. The emulsion turbidity is a function of concentration and the size of particle (Vincent, 1947).
The size of droplets of the citronella nano emulsions is shown in (Table 2 and Fig. 4). The average droplet size of citronella nano emulsions with different concentrations of neem oil ranged from 8.12 ± 2.80 nm to 12.04 ± 3.74 nm (Fig. 5) and nano emulsion with 4.50% neem oil the (CNE9) showed the smallest size 8.12 ± 2.80 nm (Fig. 5).
Table 4 (continued)
Nanoemulsions Conc. (ppm) R. solani S. rolfsii
Inhibition (%) ED50 Inhibition (%) ED50
p-Value <0.0001 <0.0001 <0.0001 <0.0001 CV(%) 5.60 11.49 5.61 4.09 SE(d) 2.146 9.116 2.322 3.919 Tukey HSD at 1% 10.063 39.902 10.885 17.155
Means with atleast one letter common are not statistically significant using TUKEY’s Honest Significant Difference.

sections.heading: 3.3. Morphology of nano emulsions
sections.text: The morphology of neem and citronella oil’s nano emulsions, both individual as well as a number of aggregated spherical of nanomicelles, was measured by Transmission Electron Microscope (Fig. 6). Results showed that some nanomicelle clusters were present in the nano emulsion, which may be due to aggregation of nanomicelles formed during sample preparation, causing variation in particle size. Transmission electron microscopic study also revealed the presence of the spherical particles in nano emulsions.

sections.heading: 3.4. Stability of nano emulsions
sections.text: The stability of nano emulsion depends on the physicochemical characteristics of its constituents including oil phase, aqueous phase, and emulsifiers (Karthik et al., 2017). This study was carried out by centrifuging the nano emulsions (neem and citronella nano emulsions) at 3500 rpm for 30 min (Baboota et al., 2007). Results showed that the nano emulsions were physically stable at room temperature (Fig. 7). The stabilization of nanodroplets in the nano emulsions of the oil was due to the surfactant which reduced interfacial free energy providing mechanical barrier to coalescence (Reiss, 1975).

sections.heading: 3.5. pH of nano emulsions
sections.text: pH plays an important role in the stability of the emulsion system (Karthik et al., 2017). The pH of neem and citronella oil’s nano emulsions measured are given in Table 3. The pH values of neem nano emulsions ranged from 3.53–4.51 and that of citronella nano emulsions from 2.30 to 5.85. No relation was found for the pH change with increasing concentrations of plant oils in nano emulsions.

sections.heading: 3.6. Antifungal activity of neem nano emulsions against R. solani and S. rolfsii
sections.text: Different concentrations viz., 7.80, 15.625, 31.25, 62.50, 125 and 250 ppm of neem nano emulsions were screened for their antifungal activity against R. solani and S. rolfsii by poisoned food technique (Sharma and Tripathi, 2008). The neem nano emulsions (NNEs) showed excellent fungicidal activity against R. solani and S. rolfsii and their ED50 values are given in Table 4 and . ED50 values were found to vary from 13.67 to 109.71 mg L−1 for R. solani and 14.71 to 85.97 mg L−1 for S. rolfsii (Fig. 10). Among, the screened neem nano emulsions, NNE10 was found to be most effective against both R. solani (ED50 13.67 mg L−1) and S. rolfsii (ED50 14.71 mg L−1), but it has statistically insignificant difference with NNE9. The results also showed that the ED50 of neem nano emulsions (NNEs) against R. solani and S. rolfsii decrease with increase in the amount of citronella oil from (0.50 to 5%). The data further revealed that nano emulsions showed significant fungicidal activity against, R. solani and S. rolfsii compared to neem oil. It has also been reported that nano emulsions hold promise as an antimicrobial agent (Lawrence and Rees, 2000).

sections.heading: 3.7. Antifungal activity of citronella nano emulsions against R. solani and S. rolfsii
sections.text:
Similarly, different concentrations (7.80, 15.625, 31.25, 62.50, 125 and 250 ppm) of citronella nano emulsions were evaluated for their antifungal activity against R. solani and S. rolfsii by the poisoned food technique and the ED50 values of different nano emulsions are given in Table 5 and Fig. 13. The citronella nano emulsions (CNEs) showed excellent fungicidal activity against R. solani and S. rolfsii (Figs. 11 and 12). The results showed that the ED50 of citronella nano emulusions (CNEs) against R. solani and S. rolfsii decrease with increase the amount of neem oil (0.50–5%). ED50 values were statistically significant and varied from 25.64 to 311.04 mg L−1 for R. solani and 20.88 to
Table 5 (continued)
Nanoemulsions Conc. (ppm) R. solani S. rolfsii
Inhibition (%) ED50 (ppm) Inhibition (%) ED50 (ppm)
p-Value <0.0001 <0.0001 <0.0001 <0.0001 CV(%) 3.06 35.09 5.28 12.02 SE(d) 1.072 48.093 1.962 17.203 Tukey HSD at 1% 5.0248 210.51 9.1973 75.301
Means with atleast one letter common are not statistically significant using TUKEY's Honest Significant Difference.
405.75 mg L−1 for S. rolfsii (Table 5). Table 5 shows that citronella nano emulsion, CNE10, is most active against both R. solani (ED50 25.64 mg L−1) and S. rolfsii (ED50 20.88 mg L−1), but statistically insignificant with CNE9. The data revealed that nano emulsion showed significant fungicidal activity against, R. solani and S. rolfsii compared to citronella oil.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text: Citronella essential oil and neem oil mixture based nano emulsions developed and standardized showed potent antifungal activity against phytopathogenic fungi compared individual oil of citronella and neem oils. This finding could be an important step towards the utilisation of citronella oil which has never been reported to be used in combination with neem oil or vice versa as bio-pesticides for controlling of plant diseases caused by R. solani and S. rolfsii. The developed and standardized nano emulsions (NNE10 and CNE10) will be further tested under field conditions to know the efficacy of the nano emulsions in natural environmental conditions.

sections.heading: Acknowledgments
sections.text: Authors thank the Head, Division of Agricultural Chemicals, IARI, New Delhi for providing facilities to carry out the research work. Eisa O. M. A thanks Indian Council of Agricultural Research (ICAR), New Delhi and African Union for financial support.

referenceMentions.context: The agricultural crop loss due to insect pests, diseases, nematodes and weeds has been recorded up to 50% in spite of the application of modern crop protection measures (Devakumar and Kumar, 2007).
These phytopathogenic fungi infect seeds, seedlings and mature plants in the field causing many diseases such as collar rot, wilt, damping off and dry root rot (Nisha et al., 2009).
solani, a soil borne pathogenic fungi, is known to have wide range of hosts and is a threat worldwide (Agrios, 2015; Woodhall et al., 2007).

solani, first reported from Japan (Miyake, 1910), is emerging as a very destructive disease under favorable weather conditions in rice growing areas of the world which ultimately causes substantial yield losses (Ali et al.

In recent years, a large number of synthetic fungicides have been banned in western world because of their undesirable attributes such as acute toxicity, long degradation periods, accumulation in food chain and toxicity to non- targeted organisms (Maria et al., 2011).

In addition to a wide group of secondary metabolites such as flavonoids, terpenoids, sulphur compounds, saponins, cyanogenic glycosides and glucosinolates (Dissanayake and Jayasinghe, 2013), essential oil, a complex mixture of organic compounds from the plants are reported to have antibacterial, antifungal, antiviral, antiparasitic and antidermatophytic properties (Tabassum and Vidyasagar, 2013), which could be useful to develop effective biopesticide of plant origin.

Juss (Family: Meliaceae), commonly known as neem, is native of south-eastern Asia, mainly cultivated in Indian subcontinent and used for the development of industrial products (Jerobin et al., 2012).
It possesses medicinal, antibacterial, antifungal and pest control properties and rich source of azadirachtin, an insect control agent (Lucantoni et al., 2006; Rodina et al., 2014; Chary, 2011).

Nano emulsions are known as isotropic, theromdynaically stable, transparent system of oil, water and surfactant with a droplet size usually range of 10–100 nm (Shafiq et al., 2007; Mei et al., 2003).

It is reported that spontaneous emulsification of essential oils into nano emulsion is simple and cost-effective (Chang et al., 2013).
The bioactive essential oils which are volatile and sensitive to degradation are suitable for such nano emulsions (Jhones et al., 2014).

There is a report in literature which showed that no precipitation occurred in the nano emulsion formulation of β-cypermethrin on dilution in contrast to commercial microemulsion with slower release (Zeng et al., 2008).

Similarly, nano emulsion of neem oil showed increased larvicidal effect against Culex quinquefasciatus and LC50 decreased with droplet size, indicating an increased uptake of smaller droplets (Anjali et al., 2012).
Nano emulsion formulations of citronella were prepared by cavitation-assisted techniques (Agrawal et al., 2017).
Primary emulsions were prepared using spontaneous emulsification procedure (Chang et al., 2013).

In this analysis, a drop of neem nano emulsions and citronella nano emulsions were placed on carbon-coated copper grids (400 mesh size) and allowed to dry in vacuum (Baboota et al., 2007), washed with distilled water and stained with a negative stain (2% uranyl acetate).
The stability of neem and citronella nano emulsions were determined by centrifuging the nano emulsions at 3500 rpm for 30 min (Shafiq and Shakeel, 2010).

The mycelial growth (mm) of the fungi both in treated (T) and control (C) was measured diametrically in three different directions and percent inhibition in radial growth (I) was calculated using the formula (Vincent, 1947).
Tween-20 was used as surfactant because non-ionic surfactants are known to be less affected by pH and ionic strength (Reddy and Fogler, 1981).

metadata.abstractText: Biopesticides are considered to be safe, target specific, biodegradable and eco-friendly. These, especially Azadirachta indica A. Juss. (neem) based biopesticides, are mainly used as emulsified concentrate (EC). There is growing interest in nano emulsions based on phytochemical mixtures due to their better efficacy compared to conventional biopesticides. A. indica seed oil and Cymbopogon nardus (L.) Rendle (Citronella) oil are known to have pest control properties. However, their utilization is often restricted due to relatively low water solubility. This drawback can be overcome by encapsulating oils in oil-in-water (O/W) emulsions or nano emulsions using low or high energy methods. In this study, various nano emulsions of crude neem and citronella oils with surfactants were developed and characterised by Dynamic Light Scattering (DLS) and Transmission Electron Microscope (TEM). Composition of various ingredients of nano emulsions was standardised. TEM study showed the spherical shape of neem and citronella oil nano emulsions. The average size of droplets of neem nano emulsion (NNE) with different percentage of citronella oil ranged from 11.23 ± 3.86 nm to 17.80 ± 4.52 nm while that of citronella nano emulsion (CNE) with different percentage of neem oil ranged from 8.12 ± 2.80 nm to 12.04 ± 3.74 nm. It was found that increase in surfactant ratio to neem oil or citronella oil decreases the size of droplets in nano emulsions. Further, in vitro antifungal study of against Rhizoctonia solani and Sclerotium rolfsii was carried out by poisoned food technique. Results showed that neem nano emulsion 10 (NNE10) and citronella nano emulsion 10 (CNE10) were most active against R. solani (ED50 13.67 mg L and 25.64 mg L) and S. rolfsii (ED50 14.71 mg L and 20.88 mg L). The standardization of the composition and development of citronella essential oil and neem oil based nano emulsions and their antifungal activity against these two fungi has been reported for the first time.
